The docile giants do what they can to avoid confrontation whenever possible. If they sense danger approaching, giant tapirs make a loud whistling sound to warn other tapirs about predators. A community who befriends or domesticates a herd of tapirs can use this whistling habit as an alarm system against encroaching enemies.

Giant tapirs are usually quite placid, but they can be fearsome when roused. Their tusk-like front teeth are suitable for gouging attackers, and a tapir that manages to get a mouthful of an enemy's arm or leg can use its blunt molars to grind the flesh to paste. Tapirs have good hearing and an excellent sense of smell, but like many prey animals, they have poor vision. In the chaos of combat against multiple enemies, giant tapirs can become overwhelmed and confused, lashing out at allies as well as foes or fleeing the scene entirely.

action->Grinding Bite.name: Grinding Bite
action->Grinding Bite.description:
Requirements The giant tapir's last action was a successful jaws Strike against a creature

Effect The tapir gnaws the target's flesh and muscle with its blunt teeth. The creature must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:18] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} until the start of its next turn.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[2d4[bludgeoning]] damage and is enfeebled 1 until the end of its next turn.

Critical Failure The creature takes @Damage[4d4[bludgeoning]] damage and is enfeebled 1 for 1 minute.

action->Snared.name: Snared
action->Snared.description: Due to the poison barbs stuck in its hooves, the tapir can't Stride farther than 10 feet.

action->Splayed Toes.name: Splayed Toes
action->Splayed Toes.description: Giant tapirs ignore difficult terrain from mud and shallow water.

Glyptodon.name: Glyptodon
Glyptodon.publicNotes:
Glyptodons are enormous, armadillo-like megafauna that roam sandy riverbanks and ancient forests in search of their favorite foods, namely riparian grass and tender saplings. Surly and suspicious, glyptodons avoid predators not out of a defensive instinct-their armored hides protect them from most well-equipped carnivores-but rather because they simply prefer to be left alone to their placid foraging. Despite their great size, glyptodons can survive on surprisingly little food, and they'll eat just about anything. As a result, they're more likely to be encountered roaming across vast tundra or desert regions than other large herbivores, appearing as a single, lumbering hump against an otherwise-flat horizon.

A glyptodon's scutes-the thick, bony plates of its carapace-grow in distinctive patterns and scar readily, making it easy for non-glyptodons to identify individual animals. Glyptodons have notoriously bad eyesight, even for prey animals, and rely on their sense of smell to get around and identify threats and each other. In combat, they primarily rely on their thick carapaces to protect them from attackers.

Although southern merchants have occasionally attempted to create a glyptodon-mounted trading network, riding these giants is an exercise in frustration, as their rounded hides provide little purchase for humanoid riders' feet or saddles. However, some webbed-toed people of the plains, including bands of lizardfolk, have managed to maintain glyptodon mounts thanks to their strong, flexible, clawed feet. Other ancestries primarily view glyptodons as a source of meat and tough hides, the latter of which make for excellent impromptu shelters and river boats.

When cornered, a glyptodon uses its powerful digging claws to scrape or scare away attackers. Glyptodons can use their tails to ward off smaller predators, but generally do so only as a last resort.

action->Carapace Block.name: Carapace Block
action->Carapace Block.description:
Trigger An adjacent creature targets the glyptodon with an attack

Effect The glyptodon turns, blocking the attack with its carapace and thrusting its heavy body toward the attacker. It gains a +2 circumstance bonus to its AC against the triggering attack. If the attack critically fails, the glyptodon attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.7blmbDrQFNfdT731]{Shove} the attacker.

action->Deny Advantage.name: Deny Advantage
action->Deny Advantage.description: A Graylok ambusher isn't @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden}, undetected, or flanking creatures of 8th level or lower or creatures of 8th level or lower using sneak attack. However, such creatures can still help other creatures flank.

action->Ice Stride.name: Ice Stride
action->Ice Stride.description: A frost giant isn't impeded by difficult terrain caused by snow or ice, nor do they need to attempt Acrobatics checks to keep from falling on slippery ice.

action->Ignite Greataxe.name: Ignite Greataxe
action->Ignite Greataxe.description: The Graylok artillerist combines gelatin and other substances over their greataxe to ignite it. For 1 minute, the greataxe gains the fire trait, and creatures hit by it take 4 persistent fire damage.

action->Throw Bomb.name: Throw Bomb
action->Throw Bomb.description:
Requirements The Graylok artillerist has two free hands

Effect The Graylok artillerist Interacts with a firebomb and then throws it at a point within 100 feet. The bomb erupts in a @Template[burst|distance:10], and works as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-srd.Item.gWr4q4HiyGhETA8H]{moderate alchemist fire}, except it inflicts @Damage[4d6[fire]] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:23|basic] save. Creatures that fail or critically fail this save also take @Damage[4[persistent,fire]] damage.

action->Wide Swing.name: Wide Swing
action->Wide Swing.description: The frost giant makes a single greataxe Strike and compares the attack roll result to the ACs of up to two foes within their reach. This counts as two attacks for the frost giant's multiple attack penalty.

action->Freeze Blade.name: Freeze Blade
action->Freeze Blade.description: The frost giant gatebreaker breathes on the blade of their battleaxe, coating it in a layer of magical ice. For 1 minute, the frost giant's battleaxe Strikes gain the cold trait, and creatures struck by the battleaxe are @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1}; at the end of each of their turns, the slowed creature can attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:23] save to end the condition.

action->Ice Stride.name: Ice Stride
action->Ice Stride.description: A frost giant isn't impeded by difficult terrain caused by snow or ice, nor do they need to attempt Acrobatics checks to keep from falling on slippery ice.

action->Shielded Stride.name: Shielded Stride
action->Shielded Stride.description: When the frost giant gatebreaker has their shield up, they can Stride to move half their Speed without triggering reactions that are triggered by their movement (such as Attacks of Opportunity).

action->Trampling Ram.name: Trampling Ram
action->Trampling Ram.description:
Requirements Another frost giant gatebreaker has Readied to Stride on the frost giant gatebreaker's order

Effect The two frost giants Stride, with a maximum distance equal to the slowest giant's Speed. Every creature whose space they move through takes @Damage[(2d8+9)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:23|basic]); creatures who fail their save fall @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}. At the end of their movement, the giants make a single Strike with a +20 modifier (reach 15 feet), inflicting 4d6+16 bludgeoning damage on a hit and knocking the target prone. If the giants hit, they can immediately attempt to Shove the creature as a free action.

Groplit.name: Groplit
Groplit.publicNotes:
The groplit is a squat little animal shaped like a water droplet, with a bulbous rear end and an eel-like face that juts from a narrow skull. Its rear legs are more muscular than those in front, which it primarily uses for balance, giving it the gait and appearance of a toad. Groplits are best known for their greasy skin and queasy hygienic habits: they spend most of each day using their two long tongues to slurp up their own oily excretions or similarly viscous discharge originating from plants or other animals. Although they prefer to dwell in northern wetlands, fens, and moist caves, groplits can thrive in all but the most barren environments. They'll eat just about anything, though they tend to prefer small, crunchy animals like bugs and birds.

Groplits are famously loyal and highly sociable companions, and they make for dedicated, if somewhat odd-looking, pets. They can be taught simple commands and appear to take great pride in obeying them, performing stunts even in the face of obvious danger. An unscrupulous master might train a groplit with the intent to sacrifice it in an emergency, a fate to which the groplit is happily resigned. This single-minded obedience and their slow reproductive rate make groplits fairly rare in the wild.

As a result of the way their bones are structured, groplits exhibit an imperturbable smile, of sorts-a physical feature which some find as creepy (or enraging) as others find it endearing. Its apparently ceaseless jubilation has given this creature the nickname "the grinning toad" in some parts of the world.

Because they love to lap up oily matter of all kinds, groplits are naturally drawn to greasy animals like @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-monster-core.Actor.tashopA1s2fAbSXA]{Slurks}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.pathfinder-bestiary-2.Actor.g1htYgARxNKxc7MV]{Giant Slugs}, and lagofirs. For the most part, such animals rarely mind the company of an amiable groplit, though there's no such thing as a free meal; groplits who drop their guard amid their found family often end up on the wrong side of their companions' intestinal tracts.

action->Flammable Grease.name: Flammable Grease
action->Flammable Grease.description: A groplit's DC to recover from persistent fire damage is increased by 2 (generally, from DC 15 to DC 17).

Hail of Razor Stones.name: Hail of Razor Stones
Hail of Razor Stones.descriptionHazard: When a concealed cord is tripped, several sharp stones fall onto the square containing the cord.
Hail of Razor Stones.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:18|name:Cut the Trip Cord|traits:hazard,mechanical,trap] (trained) to safely cut the trip cord

action->Deadfall.name: Deadfall
action->Deadfall.description:
Trigger A creature walks into the square containing the trip cord

Effect Falling rocks deal @Damage[4d8[slashing]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:19|basic]) to any creature in the square, possibly pinning them to the ground. On a failed save, the creature falls @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}; on a critical failure, the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} (DC 17 to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.SkZAQRkLLkmBQNB9]{Escape}).

An adjacent creature can attempt a @Check[athletics|dc:19] check to shove the rocks aside to free an immobilized creature.

Hall Of Fiery Doom.name: Hall Of Fiery Doom
Hall Of Fiery Doom.descriptionHazard: While the roof is on fire and collapsing timbers crush those within the hall, demons fly down from the sky to pluck victims from the flames.
Hall Of Fiery Doom.disable: Two @Check[athletics|dc:32] or @Check[diplomacy|dc:32] checks to douse the flames; Athletics to do the work yourself or Diplomacy to muster the ghostly soldiers. This reduces the hazard's actions by 1 and prevents it from using Burning Timbers. Banish the demons with up to two @Check[arcana|dc:35], @Check[occultism|dc:35], or @Check[religion|dc:35]checks; each success reduces the hazard's actions by 1, and two successes prevent it from using Demonic Abduction. When the hazard loses all 3 actions, Burning Timbers, and Demonic Abduction, it's disabled.
Hall Of Fiery Doom.reset: The hall falls quiet for 24 hours, after which it can trigger again.
Hall Of Fiery Doom.routine: (3 actions) The haunt spends 1 action to fill the hall with burning timbers falling from above, and 2 actions to pluck up random victims and drop them to their deaths.

action->Burst of Fire.name: Burst of Fire
action->Burst of Fire.description:
Trigger A creature enters the hall or ends its turn in the hall

Effect The hall bursts into flame, dealing @Damage[4d6[fire]] damage to each creature in the hall. The haunt then rolls initiative.

action->Burning Timbers.name: Burning Timbers
action->Burning Timbers.description: Creatures within the 30-foot by 90-foot area of the hall take @Damage[(4d6+12)[fire]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:29|basic]).

strike-melee->Demonic Abduction.name: Demonic Abduction
strike-melee->Demonic Abduction.description: Spectral demons lift a single creature 50 feet into the air and drop it. The haunt makes a Strike against the creature with a +23 attack bonus. On a success, the creature is lifted into the air and dropped, taking @Damage[25[bludgeoning]|options:fall-damage], though it might negate some or all this damage using a spell, such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.TTwOKGqmZeKSyNMH]{Gentle Landing}. On a critical hit, the creature also takes @Damage[(2d12+13)[slashing]] damage as the demons' claws tear through its flesh.

consumable->Potion of Fire Resistance (M.name: Potion of Fire Resistance (Moderate)
consumable->Potion of Fire Resistance (M.description:
Drinking this thick, fortifying potion grants resistance 10 against fire damage for 1 hour.

Activate A Interact

action->Evasion.name: Evasion
action->Evasion.description: When Hegremon rolls a success on a Reflex save, he gets a critical success instead.

Hobji.name: Hobji
Hobji.allSavesBonus: +2 status to all saves vs. disease and poison

equipment->Snare Kit (Specialist).name: Snare Kit (Specialist)
equipment->Snare Kit (Specialist).description: This kit contains tools and materials for creating snares. A snare kit allows you to Craft snares using the Crafting skill. A specialist snare kit gives you a +1 item bonus to the check.

action->+2 Status to All Saves vs. Disea.name: +2 Status to All Saves vs. Disease and Poison

consumable->Healing Potion (Greater).name: Healing Potion (Greater)
consumable->Healing Potion (Greater).description:
Activate A (manipulate)

A healing potion is a vial of a ruby-red liquid that imparts a tingling sensation as the drinker's wounds heal rapidly. When you drink a healing potion, you regain @Damage[(6d8+20)[healing]] Hit Points.

action->Capture Magic.name: Capture Magic
action->Capture Magic.description:
Trigger Ivarsa succeeds at a save against a foe's harmful spell, or a foe fails a spell attack roll against her with a harmful spell

Effect Ivarsa enters her Arcane Cascade. If she's already in Arcane Cascade, she gains a +2 status bonus to damage from Arcane Cascade until the end of her next turn.

action->Arcane Cascade.name: Arcane Cascade
action->Arcane Cascade.description:
Requirements Ivarsa can enter this stance only if her most recent action was to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.aBQ8ajvEBByv45yz]{Cast a Spell} or make a Spellstrike, but she can remain in the stance even if she no longer meets the requirements

Effect When she enters this stance and at the beginning of each of her turns while she's in it, Ivarsa gains 6 temporary Hit Points. While in this stance, Ivarsa's melee Strikes gain the arcane trait, deal 2 extra fire damage, and deal @Damage[(4[splash])[fire]]{4 splash fire} damage to foes adjacent to her target.

weapon->Staff of Divination.name: Staff of Divination
weapon->Staff of Divination.description:
Semiprecious gemstones emerge, seemingly at random, from the surface of this gnarled wooden staff. While wielding it, you gain a +2 circumstance bonus to checks to identify divination magic.

Activate Cast a Spell

Effect You expend a number of charges from the staff to cast a spell from its list.

  • Cantrip @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.gpzpAAAJ1Lza2JVl]{Detect Magic}
  • 1st @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Gb7SeieEvd0pL2Eh]{Sure Strike}
  • 2nd @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.vTQvfYu2llKQedmY]{Translate}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.pZTqGY1MLRjgKasV]{Darkvision}, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.jwK43yKsHTkJQvQ9]{See the Unseen}

Craft Requirements Supply one casting of all listed levels of all listed spells.

consumable->Healing Potion (Moderate).name: Healing Potion (Moderate)
consumable->Healing Potion (Moderate).description:
Activate A (manipulate)

A healing potion is a vial of a ruby-red liquid that imparts a tingling sensation as the drinker's wounds heal rapidly. When you drink a healing potion, you regain @Damage[(3d8+10)[healing]] Hit Points.

action->Child of Winter.name: Child of Winter
action->Child of Winter.description: When Jesseri Casts a Spell that deals damage and doesn't have a duration, she deals additional cold damage that's equal to the spell's rank and ignores cold resistance 10.

action->Signature Spells.name: Signature Spells
action->Signature Spells.description: Jesseri can heighten @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.rfZpqmj0AIIdkVIs]{Heal} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9AAkVUCwF6WVNNY2]{Lightning Bolt} to any level for which she has an available spell slot.

Kadlaka.name: Kadlaka
Kadlaka.publicNotes: Kadlakas-strong, lanky humanoids with raven-like features-combine the most formidable aspects of talented hunters and airborne scouts, to say nothing of their potent magical powers over thunder and lightning. Though they shy from most humanoids, kadlakas readily form friendships with ravens and other birds, and they sometimes make temporary alliances with people who prove themselves capable stewards of wild animals and the natural order of things. When they do settle on a roost-whether for a single season or a lifetime-kadlakas often position themselves as guardians of a natural feature or local flock. Because a kadlaka's natural form might frighten humanoid travelers, they often take on the guise of a human or other common bipedal ancestry to gain information and pass on warnings.

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description:
The kadlaka can change their appearance to that of a Medium humanoid. This doesn't change their Speed or their attack and damage modifiers with their Strikes but might change the type of damage their melee Strikes deal (typically to bludgeoning). While in their humanoid shape, the kadlaka can't use Wingbeat. Each kadlaka has a fixed humanoid form-they can't adopt a different appearance each time they use this ability.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]

action->Silent Lightning.name: Silent Lightning
action->Silent Lightning.description: A kadlaka's movements are practically silent. Against a creature using only hearing to perceive them, they gain a +4 circumstance bonus to their Stealth check. As normal, this benefit also improves the kadlaka's Stealth DC.

Lagofir.name: Lagofir
Lagofir.publicNotes:
Lagofirs are semiaquatic omnivores that resemble a rabbit the size of a large dog. They're social creatures, playful but territorial and protective of their kin. Lagofirs live in family units and gather in larger groups as often as their environment allows. They're commonly found in northern Avistan, congregating along rivers, lakes, and coasts, where they subsist on fish, crustaceans, marine plants, and small mammals.

Lagofirs have a stout body, rounded back, large hind legs, long ears, and a short, fluffy tail. Their powerful incisors are capable of cracking through clam shells, chitin, and bone. Both their front and back paws are webbed, and their front paws are highly dexterous, enabling them to grasp objects and perform simple manual tasks.

Lagofirs secrete a thick, sweet-smelling, flammable oil that coats their fur. Warm to the touch, this oil keeps them insulated and comfortable in frigid water and cold climates. Lagofirs mark their territory by brushing against solid surfaces, coating them in oil that, to other lagofirs, identifies an individual. This makes their lairs, known as burrows or forms, incredibly hazardous. A single spark in a lagofir form can cause an explosion.

action->Cold Adaptation.name: Cold Adaptation
action->Cold Adaptation.description: The lagofir reduces the effects it suffers from cold environments by one step.

action->Consuming Fumes.name: Consuming Fumes
action->Consuming Fumes.description: 15 feet. The lagofir is surrounded by fumes from the flammable oil it exudes. Each nonmagical open flame the size of a torch or larger within the emanation explodes, dealing @Damage[4d4[fire]] damage to all creatures and objects adjacent to the flame (@Check[reflex|dc:17|basic]). After exploding, the fire source is extinguished.

Loblobi.name: Loblobi
Loblobi.publicNotes:
In the First World, rivers don't always flow as expected; sometimes they run backward, upward, or just disappear into mist and reappear somewhere else entirely. Fey native to such rivers are often just as capricious. This quality is particularly true of loblobis, cunning carnivores who resemble small, chubby humans with the heads and wings of crested herons.

These malicious tricksters love playing any pranks that result in other creatures being embarrassed, hurt, or even drowned. Their most common "antic" is to cast @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.Seaah9amXg70RKw2]{Water Walk} on a hopeful river-crosser, only to dismiss the spell when their victim has traversed halfway across. Conversely, most loblobis are terrible sports when they're the butt of a joke. It's common wisdom that few creatures can hold a grudge like a loblobi.

Exceptionally vain, loblobis flutter and dance constantly to show off their plumage. Failing to comment on a preening loblobi's appearance is a sure method to invite eternal enmity, but flattery might buy enough time to sneak away from the evil fey.

spell->Water Walk (At Will) (Loblobi Can.name: Water Walk (At Will) (Loblobi Can Dismiss the Spell)

spell->Prestidigitation (Only to Move, C.name: Prestidigitation (Only to Move, Clean, or Soil Small Amounts of Water)

action->Unflappable Self-Importance.name: Unflappable Self-Importance
action->Unflappable Self-Importance.description:
When a loblobi rolls a success on a Will save against an emotion effect or an effect that would make it controlled, it gets a critical success instead. When it rolls a critical failure against such an effect, it gets a failure instead.

However, a loblobi is vulnerable to flattery. It takes a -4 circumstance penalty to its Will and Perception DCs against any fulsome Deception and Diplomacy checks to Lie, @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.OX4fy22hQgUHDr0q]{Make an Impression}, or Request.

shield->Sturdy Shield (Lesser).name: Sturdy Shield (Lesser)
shield->Sturdy Shield (Lesser).description:
With a superior design and excellent craftsmanship, this steel shield has higher Hardness than its non-magical counterparts, making it harder to break and destroy.

The shield has Hardness 10, HP 80, and BT 40.

action->Aura of Courage.name: Aura of Courage
action->Aura of Courage.description: 15 feet. Whenever Lomok becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened}, reduce the condition value by 1 (minimum 0). At the end of his turn, when he would reduce his frightened condition value by 1, also reduce the value by 1 for all allies in his aura.

Long-horned Bison.name: Long-horned Bison
Long-horned Bison.publicNotes: Much like their smaller bison cousins, long-horned bison are bovines with short faces, two horns, a shaggy coat, and a noticeable hump on their back. Despite their relation to more placid bovines, however, long-horned bison are ill-tempered and territorial. Their tread shakes the ground, while the thunder of their stampedes can be mistaken for an earthquake. Long-horned bison weigh upwards of 4,500 pounds and measure up to 9 feet tall and 16 feet long. Their horns, measured tip to tip, can be almost as wide as the bison are tall.

Megaloceros.name: Megaloceros
Megaloceros.publicNotes: The megaloceros is similar in form to the elk, but far superior in size. The average male's antlers weigh nearly 100 pounds and can be wider than his body is long. Megaloceroses stand up to 9 feet tall, weigh 1,500 pounds, and grow antlers over 12 feet wide.

action->Furious Charge.name: Furious Charge
action->Furious Charge.description: The megaloceros Strides twice and makes a hoof Strike after either Stride. If the Strike hits, the megaloceros deals an additional @Damage[2d4[bludgeoning]] damage.

Methane Flue.name: Methane Flue
Methane Flue.descriptionHazard: Invisible but highly flammable natural gas has built up beneath the ground, where geological pressure can ignite it.
Methane Flue.disable: @Check[survival|dc:28|name:Diffuse the Flames|traits:environmental,hazard] to dig around the vent in a way that diffuses the fumes

action->Flame Spurt.name: Flame Spurt
action->Flame Spurt.description:
Trigger A creature moves within 5 feet of the flue

Effect A fiery geyser of flaming gas explodes from the ground. Creatures within 5 feet of the flue take @Damage[4d10[fire]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:30|basic]); creatures that fail the save also take @Damage[4d10[persistent,fire]] damage.

action->Dual Deny Advantage.name: Dual Deny Advantage
action->Dual Deny Advantage.description: Due to his dual nature with Xeleria, Metuak is never @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard}.

action->Axe Master.name: Axe Master
action->Axe Master.description: Metuak has access to the critical specialization effect of axe weapons. Due to his hatchet's grievous rune, he can damage a third creature with the same restrictions.

action->Dual Soul.name: Dual Soul
action->Dual Soul.description: A demon named Xeleria is bound to Metuak's soul. Though the two entities share one body and are a single creature for the purpose of both targeted and area effects, Metuak and Xeleria each have 120 Hit Points. Damage to each is tracked separately. Xeleria's HP is reduced by force, good, and vitality damage, and any damage from a cold iron weapon, a weapon with a ghost touch rune, and any damage originating from the Primordial Flame. All other damage reduces Metuak's HP.Metuak and Xeleria must both be reduced to 0 HP for Metuak to die and Xeleria to be destroyed. If, at the beginning of Metuak's turn, either Metuak or Xeleria has been reduced to 0 HP but the other hasn't, Metuak and Xeleria each regain 15 HP.

action->Shadow Blend.name: Shadow Blend
action->Shadow Blend.description: Metuak Strides up to twice his Speed. If he ends his movement in an area of dim light, he is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} as long as he remains in dim light.

action->Soul Swipe.name: Soul Swipe
action->Soul Swipe.description: Metuak makes a single hatchet or claw Strike and compares the result to the AC of up to four foes, each of whom must be within his reach. He rolls damage once and applies it to each creature he hits. A Soul Swipe counts as two attacks for his multiple attack penalty. Metuak's hatchet applies its sweep trait against all four targets.

action->Terrifying Howl.name: Terrifying Howl
action->Terrifying Howl.description: Metuak unleashes a terrifying howl, attempting to Demoralize each creature within 30 feet. These creatures are then immune to Terrifying Howl for 1 minute.

Necrohusk.name: Necrohusk
Necrohusk.publicNotes:
Necrohusks are skittering, undead monstrosities, created when a humanoid is purposefully twisted into a new creature through necromantic experimentation. Unlike fleshwarps and recipients of successful necrografts, prospective necrohusks never survive the procedure. After reanimation, they're cunning, animalistic creatures that follow their creator's orders without question.

Creating a necrohusk is an incredibly difficult endeavor, fraught with error. Most attempts result in lumps of useless, rotten slurry or malformed undead no more cunning or dangerous than a mundane zombie. The costs in time, experimental subjects, and expensive spell components lead some would-be necromancers to conclude that the results aren't worth the risk. Occasionally, spellcasters can harness the power of the Void during the process, which lessens the monetary cost but vastly increases the danger, often producing a deadly backlash resulting in the creator's death and a masterless necrohusk.

Among the Sutaki, only Ashen Swale and his lieutenants, Turkek and Azi, have the skill and knowledge to create necrohusks with any regularity, although Turkek's interests often lead him away from such gruesome endeavors. Necrohusks are created from volunteers in Ashen Swale's cult or from traitorous Sutaki whom Ashen Swale wants to punish with a ghastly fate.

action->Skitter.name: Skitter
action->Skitter.description:
Trigger A creature misses the necrohusk with a melee Strike

Effect The necrohusk Steps.

Oil Explosion.name: Oil Explosion
Oil Explosion.descriptionHazard: The flammable oil catches flame and explodes, burning up in a ball of fire.
Oil Explosion.disable: @Check[survival|dc:25|name:Neutralize the oil|traits:hazard,environmental,fire] (trained) or @Check[crafting|dc:23|name:Neutralize the oil|traits:hazard,environmental,fire] to neutralize the oil without setting it alight

action->Explode.name: Explode
action->Explode.description:
Trigger An open flame is brought into area A4

Effect The oil on the walls explodes, dealing @Damage[(4d8+10)[fire]] damage to all creatures and objects in areas A4 and A3(@Check[reflex|dc:21|traits:hazard,environmental,fire|basic]).

weapon->Tallow Bomb (Moderate).name: Tallow Bomb (Moderate)
weapon->Tallow Bomb (Moderate).description:
Activate A Strike

A mixture of rendered animal fat and acids designed to ignite the fat when exposed to air, a tallow bomb creates a splash of burning oil that adheres to skin, clothes, and hair. A tallow bomb deals the listed fire damage, persistent fire damage, and splash damage.

On a critical hit, a living creature taking persistent fire damage from a tallow bomb is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} from the stench of burning fat and can't reduce its sickened value below 1 while the persistent fire damage lasts.

You gain a +1 item bonus to attack rolls. The bomb deals 2d4 persistent fire damage and 2 fire splash damage.

action->Death Throes.name: Death Throes
action->Death Throes.description: When a frost worm dies, it explodes in a @Template[burst|distance:100] of searing cold blood. All creatures and objects in range take @Damage[10d8[cold]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:29|basic] save).

action->Human Cunning.name: Human Cunning
action->Human Cunning.description: Pakano's allies are unaffected by his worm chill aura and Worm Trill, and his Freezing Blood affects random enemies instead of random creatures. His Death Throes, however, still affect all creatures and objects in a 100-foot burst.

action->Worm Chill.name: Worm Chill
action->Worm Chill.description: 5 feet. A creature that enters or begins its turn in the emanation takes @Damage[3d6[cold]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:29|basic]).

Pouncing Tiger Haunt.name: Pouncing Tiger Haunt
Pouncing Tiger Haunt.descriptionHazard: A cave painting of a great cat roars to life and leaps off the wall to attack.
Pouncing Tiger Haunt.disable: @Check[nature|dc:18|name:Quell the Spirit|traits:hazard,haunt] (trained) or @Check[religion|dc:18|name:Quell the Spirit|traits:hazard,haunt] (trained) to quell the spirit
Pouncing Tiger Haunt.reset: If the cave painting isn't destroyed, the haunt resets after 1 day.

action->Tiger Slash.name: Tiger Slash
action->Tiger Slash.description:
Trigger A living creature approaches within 5 feet of the cave painting

Effect The haunt deals @Damage[4d8[slashing]] damage with semisolid claws (@Check[will|dc:18|basic]). On a failed save, the target is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D]{Fleeing} for 1 round (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} and fleeing for 1 minute on a critical failure).

Punishing Altar.name: Punishing Altar
Punishing Altar.descriptionHazard: The bowl releases a wave of negative energy when a living creature approaches without displaying a religious symbol of Venexus.
Punishing Altar.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:22|name:Remove the bowl|traits:hazard,magical,necromancy,void,trap] (expert) to remove the bowl without triggering the magic, or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (2nd level, counteract DC 20) to counteract the runes
Punishing Altar.stealth: (trained) to notice the bowl is the center point for a magical trap

action->Necromantic Wave.name: Necromantic Wave
action->Necromantic Wave.description:
Trigger A living creature approaches within 10 feet of the bowl without displaying a religious symbol of Venexus

Effect The bowl releases a wave of necromantic energy, dealing @Damage[(4d8+10)[void]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:21|traits:hazard,magical,necromancy,void,trap|basic]) to the triggering creature and all creatures in the area not displaying a religious symbol of Venexus. On a critical failure, a creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}.

action->Counter-Charge.name: Counter-Charge
action->Counter-Charge.description:
Trigger A creature Strides within reach of the warrior and critically fails to Strike the warrior with a melee weapon

Effect The rhino warrior knocks the creature to the ground, and the triggering creature falls @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} and takes @Damage[(2d6+5)[bludgeoning]] damage. The rhino warrior is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the end of their next turn.

action->Dig In.name: Dig In
action->Dig In.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The rhino warrior makes two pick Strikes against a creature within reach. The rhino warrior rolls only one attack roll for both Strikes, then compares the result against the creature's AC. The rhino warrior's multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after both Strikes.

Rime Sludge.name: Rime Sludge
Rime Sludge.publicNotes:
Rot and decay play a natural role in swamps of all climates, and latent magical energies or other strange phenomena can transform decomposing matter into oozes and other monstrous creatures made of living muck. Tundra wetlands are no exception to this trend. Worse, in such regions, a quick freeze can prevent noxious sludge from breaking down, and sequential years of short, seasonal thaws can compress rot upon rot until the pestilential mass animates as a rime sludge. These rare, noxious oozes hungrily search for and consume any organic matter they find in their northland habitats.

Like most oozes, rime sludges consist primarily of protoplasm, though theirs has a slushy consistency peppered with disgusting nuggets of indigestible matter, such as petrified wood, jagged arrowheads, and animal fossils. A rime sludge renews this protoplasm by consuming plants and animals and maintaining a careful balance of semifrozen decomposition in its mutable form.

Rime sludges are among the few oozes that thrive in cold climates, as too much heat accelerates their natural decay. Rime sludges can't survive temperatures too far above freezing for more than a few days. Rising temperatures force them to migrate toward cooler climates or cold underground areas.

Few intelligent creatures inhabiting cold climates want anything to do with rime sludges. These oozes can't be trained, tend to wander off at random, and emit a noxious stink at the slightest hint of warmth. Some inventive creatures try to trap rime sludges in pits to keep them contained and use them to dispose of prisoners or food scraps. Because of the oozes' overpowering stench, these pits tend to be quite deep.

action->Motion Sense 60 feet.name: Motion Sense 60 feet
action->Motion Sense 60 feet.description: A rime sludge can sense nearby motion through vibration and air movement.

action->Noxious Sublimation.name: Noxious Sublimation
action->Noxious Sublimation.description: The first time each round that the rime sludge takes fire damage, a cloud of sickening decay roils outward, dealing @Damage[2d6[poison]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:17|basic]) to all creatures in a @Template[emanation|distance:10]. A creature that fails its saving throw is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 3} on a critical failure).

action->Slushy Undulation.name: Slushy Undulation
action->Slushy Undulation.description: A rime sludge ignores difficult terrain and greater difficult terrain from ice and snow and doesn't risk falling @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} when crossing ice.

Rockfall Ceiling.name: Rockfall Ceiling
Rockfall Ceiling.descriptionHazard: A load of rocks, held up by a rope pulley, is dropped on the cavern's lower level.
Rockfall Ceiling.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:25|name:Pin the pulley in place|traits:hazard,mechanical,trap] (trained) to pin the pulley in place

action->Drop Rocks.name: Drop Rocks
action->Drop Rocks.description:
Trigger A creature holding the rope pulley pulls it

Effect The net releases, dropping rocks on all creatures and objects in the lower half of area A15, dealing @Damage[(4d8+14)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:26|traits:hazard,mechanical,trap|basic]). The area then becomes difficult terrain.

Roru.name: Roru
Roru.publicNotes: Rorus, sometimes called hunter demons, are brutal fiends that arise from the souls of mortals who mutilated animal corpses. As demons, these individuals don animal pelts, then infiltrate packs or herds to corrupt entire swaths of animals, turning their victims bloodthirsty and feral.

action->Disobedience Vulnerability.name: Disobedience Vulnerability
action->Disobedience Vulnerability.description: The first time each round an attempt to Command an Animal fails within 60 feet of a roru, the roru takes @Damage[4d6[mental]] damage (@Damage[10d6[mental]] if the roru failed the attempt).

action->Predatory Aura.name: Predatory Aura
action->Predatory Aura.description: 30 feet. An animal or beast entering or starting its turn in the emanation must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:25] save or become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} (frightened 2 on a critical failure). Frightened animals within the emanation can't attack the roru. A creature that succeeds at a saving throw against predatory aura is immune for 24 hours.

Shattering Rune.name: Shattering Rune
Shattering Rune.descriptionHazard: A magical rune is inscribed on the tarry earth at the entrance to the hut, buried beneath snow, with an @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.zJxUflt9np0q4yML]{Invisible} sensor that detects creatures within a 10-foot-radius sphere.
Shattering Rune.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:30|name:Erase the Rune|traits:hazard] (master) to erase the rune without triggering the sensor or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (5th level; counteract DC 28) to dispel the rune

action->Shattering Shockwave.name: Shattering Shockwave
action->Shattering Shockwave.description:
Trigger A Small or larger creature comes within 10 feet of the rune

Effect The rune unleashes a deafening peal of thunder that deals @Damage[10d8[sonic]] damage in a 20-foot burst (@Check[reflex|dc:30|basic]).

Soul Draining Cage.name: Soul Draining Cage
Soul Draining Cage.descriptionHazard: Necromantic runes inscribed on the cage bars and lock drain the vitality of living creatures who interact with the cage.
Soul Draining Cage.disable: @Check[thievery|dc:25|name:Drain the rune's power|traits:hazard,magical,necromancy,void,trap] (expert) to drain the runes' power harmlessly or @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.9HpwDN4MYQJnW0LG]{Dispel Magic} (3rd level; counteract DC 22) to counteract the rune

action->Soul Drain.name: Soul Drain
action->Soul Drain.description:
Trigger A creature touches the cage bars, door, or lock directly or with a tool

Effect The trap deals @Damage[(4d8+18)[void]] damage to the triggering creature, creatures inside the cage, and all creatures adjacent to the cage (@Check[fortitude|dc:27|traits:hazard,trap|basic]). On a failed save, a creature is also @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}.

Spectral Archers.name: Spectral Archers
Spectral Archers.descriptionHazard: Ghostly soldiers wielding crossbows manifest within the towers that flank the gatehouse and rain bolts down upon intruders.
Spectral Archers.disable: @Check[intimidation|dc:31|traits:haunt,hazard] (expert) to cow the archers into fleeing or @Check[religion|dc:28|name:Banish the Spirits|traits:haunt,hazard] (expert) to temporarily banish the spirits
Spectral Archers.reset: The haunt vanishes permanently if the graveknights are destroyed. Otherwise, it returns after 1 hour.

action->Rain of Bolts.name: Rain of Bolts
action->Rain of Bolts.description:
Trigger A creature attacks the graveknights in area G1 or enters the castle

Effect The haunt makes a spectral bolt Strike against the triggering creature, then rolls initiative.

action->Routine.name: Routine
action->Routine.description: (1 action) The hazard fires one bolt at every creature in a 30-foot-by-30-foot area in front of the gate as 1 action. Because the spectral archers fire bolts continuously, the haunt can also use the Continuous Barrage free action (below) to fire bolts at each creature during that creature's turn.

action->Continuous Barrage.name: Continuous Barrage
action->Continuous Barrage.description:
Trigger A creature in front of the gate finishes an action

Effect The haunt makes a spectral bolt Strike against the triggering creature.

Summer Hora.name: Summer Hora
Summer Hora.privateNotes:
Summer horai appear constantly bathed in sunlight, with skin and clothing of red, orange, and yellow, like the sunlight of high summer.

The Summer Hora is under the constant effects of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.BBvV7qoXGdw09q1C]{Speak with Animals} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.qvwIwJ9QBihy8R0t]{Speak with Plants}.
Summer Hora.languagesDetails: speak with animals, speak with plants

action->Summer Bound.name: Summer Bound
action->Summer Bound.description: During the winter months, a summer hora can't take reactions, is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}, and can't reduce their sickened condition below 1.

action->Solstice Dependent.name: Solstice Dependent
action->Solstice Dependent.description: An hora is mystically bonded to a natural location with a simple astronomical calendar that marks the summer and winter solstice. If they aren't at that location at dawn when the sunlight touches the calendar, they become @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}, increasing the value by 1 for each missed day and reducing by 1 only when they witness dawn's light touch the calendar. Even on a cloudy day, there's enough sunlight to satisfy the hora's need. An hora can perform a 24-hour ritual to bond to a new location.

action->Summer's Salvation.name: Summer's Salvation
action->Summer's Salvation.description:
Trigger The summer hora or an ally within 30 feet that the summer hora can see fails a Perception check or saving throw

Effect If it's the month of the summer solstice, the hora's or ally's check retroactively gains a +4 status bonus, which can change the outcome from a critical failure to a failure or a failure to a success. If it's the month before or after the summer solstice, the check gains a retroactive +2 status bonus instead. In the other months except during the three winter solstice months, the check gains a retroactive +1 status bonus instead. During the winter solstice months, this ability has no effect. The summer hora can't use Summer's Fortune again for [[/br 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}.

Summer Hora Queen.name: Summer Hora Queen
Summer Hora Queen.privateNotes:
Hora queens rule over wide stretches of land, nourishing and protecting native animals and plants. Most hora queens watch over their regions in pairs: one summer and one winter, or one autumn and one spring.

The Summer Hora Queen is under the constant effects of @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.BBvV7qoXGdw09q1C]{Speak with Animals} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.qvwIwJ9QBihy8R0t]{Speak with Plants}.
Summer Hora Queen.languagesDetails: speak with animals, speak with plants

action->Summer Bound.name: Summer Bound
action->Summer Bound.description: During the winter months, a summer hora can't take reactions, is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}, and can't reduce their sickened condition below 1.

action->Tied to the Land.name: Tied to the Land
action->Tied to the Land.description: A summer hora queen is intrinsically tied to a specific region, such as a forest or hilly plain. For 3 months around the summer solstice, the environment is supernaturally resilient, allowing the queen to automatically attempt to counteract spells and rituals that would harm the environment, such as @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.7yWXx3qC4eFNHhxD]{Blight}, with a +27 counteract modifier and a counteract rank of 7. For the 3 months around the winter solstice, however, her warded region becomes twisted or unhealthy unless a winter hora queen is present.

action->Nymph's Beauty.name: Nymph's Beauty
action->Nymph's Beauty.description:
30 feet. Creatures that start their turn in the aura must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:30] save or suffer an effect described in the nymph queen's entry.

On a failed save, the creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} and @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} for 1 minute.

action->Site Bound.name: Site Bound
action->Site Bound.description:
Syarstik can't leave Red Cat Cave, and he rarely ever leaves area E9

A typical ghost can stray only a short distance from where it was killed or the place it haunts. A typical limit is 120 feet. Some ghosts are instead bound to a room, building, item, or creature that was special to it rather than a location.

action->Rejuvenation.name: Rejuvenation
action->Rejuvenation.description: When Syarstik is destroyed, he re-forms after [[/br 2d4 #Syarstik Rejuvenation]]{2d4 days} within area E9, fully healed. Syarstik can be permanently destroyed only by a non-possessed wielder of the Primordial Flame.

action->Motion Sense.name: Motion Sense
action->Motion Sense.description: A tar ooze can sense nearby motion through vibration and movement.

action->Sticky.name: Sticky
action->Sticky.description:
Trigger The tar ooze is hit by a melee attack

Effect The ooze attempts to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.PMbdMWc2QroouFGD]{Grapple} the creature that hit it. The ooze must still spend an action to extend the duration of the Grab on subsequent rounds, as normal.

action->Viscous Sludge.name: Viscous Sludge
action->Viscous Sludge.description: The tar ooze can have up to eight creatures grappled at the same time; doing so doesn't prevent it from making pseudopod Strikes. A tar ooze can climb on ceilings and other inverted surfaces, though such surfaces are difficult terrain.

action->Zombification.name: Zombification
action->Zombification.description: A creature slain while engulfed by a tar ooze undergoes a horrifying transformation and crawls from the ooze a week later as a tar zombie.

Tar Pit.name: Tar Pit
Tar Pit.descriptionHazard: A 15-foot-wide patch of tar covered with dirt and leaves attempts to capture creatures that step onto it.
Tar Pit.disable: @Check[survival|dc:25|name:Reveal the Tar Pit|traits:environmental,hazard] (expert) to disturb the surface and reveal the tar pit
Tar Pit.reset: Though the hazard still captures anyone who touches it, the surface doesn't become hidden again until it settles, which takes 24 hours.
Tar Pit.routine: (1 action) On its initiative, the tar pit pulls down each creature within it, thick tar adhering to the creature's body. A creature that was submerged up to its waist becomes submerged up to its neck, and a creature that was submerged up to its neck is pulled under and must hold its breath to avoid suffocation. A creature in the tar pit can attempt a @Check[athletics|dc:33] check to @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.actionspf2e.Item.pprgrYQ1QnIDGZiy]{Climb} to either raise itself by one step (if it's submerged to its neck or full submerged) or to move 5 feet if it's submerged only up to its waist. On a critical failure, the creature is pulled down one step. Other creatures can Aid the creature, typically by using a rope or similar aid or by attempting to pull the creature out with their own @Check[athletics|dc:33] check, with the same results as if the creature attempted the check. In addition to the usual results, a character adjacent to the tar pit who critically fails while Aiding moves into the tar pit. A creature that Climbs out of the tar pit escapes the hazard and lands @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} in an adjacent space.

action->Capture.name: Capture
action->Capture.description:
Trigger A Huge or smaller creature walks onto the tar pit

Effect The triggering creature sinks into the tar pit up to its waist. The tar pit rolls initiative if it hasn't already.

Tar Zombie Mammoth.name: Tar Zombie Mammoth
Tar Zombie Mammoth.privateNotes: Slow A tar zombie is permanently @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use reactions.

condition->Slowed.name: Slowed
condition->Slowed.description: You have fewer actions. Slowed always includes a value. When you regain your actions at the start of your turn, reduce the number of actions you regain by your slowed value. Because slowed has its effect at the start of your turn, you don't immediately lose actions if you become slowed during your turn.

action->Flammable.name: Flammable
action->Flammable.description: A tar zombie requires a successful DC 20 flat check to recover from persistent fire damage. This DC isn't reduced for assisted recovery.

Throttled Blindheim.name: Throttled Blindheim
Throttled Blindheim.publicNotes:
Inhabitants of damp, subterranean caves, blindheims resemble stubby humanoids with oversized, frog-like heads and bulbous eyes. Their eyes emit a soft glow at all times, but a blindheim can draw back the heavy membrane that normally covers them to emit an intense light as bright as day. These simple creatures use their lights to draw in or disorient prey, mostly small animals like lizards, rodents, or fish. However, they might go after larger prey if trying to feed their young. When they encounter creatures their own size or larger they retreat, flashing their eyes to facilitate their escape if necessary. They often hunt in pairs or small packs. Using their lights to coordinate from a distance, they slowly close in on the creatures they hunt. One common hunting pattern involves one blindheim diving deep and using its light to chase fish to the surface, while another up above snatches them up and tosses them onto the land to eat later.

Blindheims make their nests in damp caverns, especially grottoes next to underground lakes or bogs. An ideal nest rests in a cozy cavern with plenty of fungus to eat, a few fish swimming in a lake, and the comforting drip of water from the ceiling. Blindheims prefer to lead quiet and serene lives, and even when first born they emit only the meekest of vocalizations. A blindheim is born shining, and its parents cuddle over it to dim the light so as to avoid attracting predators.

It's not just animals that endanger blindheims. Underground peoples find the creatures useful and attempt to capture them for specialized purposes. Duergars use them as "raid frogs," placing heavy hoods over blindheims' heads and revealing them suddenly during raids to blind their foes. They sometimes send the creatures along with their slaves that lack darkvision into the mines as a source of light. Drow use them for some of these same purposes, and some nobles have been known to treat the creatures as mere lanterns, having them hoisted to the ceilings of their halls. Neither duergars nor drow take good care of the captive creatures, so blindheims rarely last long in captivity.

action->Crushed Windpipes.name: Crushed Windpipes
action->Crushed Windpipes.description: The blindheim can't vocalize and is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} until its neck injuries heal.

action->Spotlight.name: Spotlight
action->Spotlight.description:
Bright light shines from the blindheim's eyes in a @Template[emanation|distance:30] (also creating dim light to 60 feet). Each creature in the bright light when the blindheim uses this action, or who enters it while the light continues, must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:18] save. It is then temporarily immune for 1 hour. This light remains until the blindheim dims its eyes by using this action again.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for [[/br 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}.

Critical Failure The creature is Blinded for 1 hour.

Turkek.name: Turkek
Turkek.allSavesBonus: +2 circumstance to all saves vs. disease

equipment->Spellbook.name: Spellbook
equipment->Spellbook.description: A spellbook holds the written knowledge necessary to learn and prepare various spells, a necessity for wizards (who typically get one for free) and a useful luxury for other spellcasters looking to learn additional spells. Each spellbook can hold up to 100 spells. The Price listed is for a blank spellbook.

consumable->Wand of Widening (Darkness L.name: Wand of Widening (Darkness Level 2)
consumable->Wand of Widening (Darkness L.description:
@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.spells-srd.Item.4GE2ZdODgIQtg51c]{Darkness}

The end of this wand is forked instead of tapered.

Activate Cast a Spell; The activation takes 2 if the spell normally takes 1 to cast, or 3 if the spell normally take 2

Frequency Once per day, plus overcharge

Effect You Cast the Spell, and increase its area. Add 5 feet to the radius of a burst that normally has a radius of at least 10 feet; add 5 feet to the length of a cone or line that is normally 15 feet long or smaller; or add 10 feet to the length of a larger cone or line.

Craft Requirements Supply a casting of a spell of the appropriate rank. The spell must have a casting time of 1 or 2, can't have a duration, and must have an area of burst (10 feet or more), cone, or line.

action->+2 Circumstance to All Saves vs..name: +2 Circumstance to All Saves vs. Disease

action->Guide's Warning.name: Guide's Warning
action->Guide's Warning.description:
When Vare is about to roll a Perception or Survival check to determine her initiative, she can alert her allies as a free action. Vare visually or audibly warns allies, granting them a +1 circumstance bonus to their initiative rolls. Depending on how Vare warns allies, this action has the auditory or visual trait.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.UiISDbCjK6AUDsll]{Effect: Guide's Warning}

action->Snare Crafting.name: Snare Crafting
action->Snare Crafting.description: Vare can use the Crafting skill to create the following snares: alarm snare, hampering snare, irritating thorn snare, marking snare, signaling snare, and smoke screen snare. Vare can create four snares each day without paying for the materials, using 3 Interact actions to set up each snare.

action->Guiding Words.name: Guiding Words
action->Guiding Words.description:
Vare points out a weakness of a creature within 30 feet. Vare and all allies that can hear or see her gain a +1 status bonus to attack and damage rolls against that creature until the beginning of Vare's next turn. Vare adds an extra 1d6 precision damage to her weapon and unarmed attacks that hit that creature for the duration.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.uqjx1bwYduHwwC7d]{Effect: Guiding Words}

Venexus.name: Venexus
Venexus.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. magic

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Tail Lash.name: Tail Lash
action->Tail Lash.description:
Trigger A creature within reach of the chosen's tail Strike uses an action to Strike or attempt a skill check

Effect Venexus's chosen attempts to Strike the triggering creature with their tail. If it hits, the creature takes a -2 circumstance penalty to the triggering roll.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.QqC9xymSXSVunDgl]{Effect: Tail Lash}

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description: Venexus's chosen changes between their humanoid shape and hybrid shape. They gain a tail unarmed Strike while in their hybrid shape.

action->Flurry of Blows.name: Flurry of Blows
action->Flurry of Blows.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect Venexus's chosen makes two unarmed Strikes. If both hit the same creature, combine their damage for the purpose of resistances and weaknesses.

action->Ice Walk.name: Ice Walk
action->Ice Walk.description: Venexus's chosen ignores difficult terrain and greater difficult terrain from ice and snow and doesn't risk falling when crossing ice.

action->Powerful Fists.name: Powerful Fists
action->Powerful Fists.description: Venexus's chosen's fist Strikes are treated as cold iron and silver, and the chosen doesn't take penalties when making lethal attacks.

action->Freezing Blood.name: Freezing Blood
action->Freezing Blood.description:
Trigger An adjacent creature deals piercing or slashing damage to the wyrmling

Effect The wyrmling's blood splatters onto the triggering creature, dealing @Damage[1d4[cold]] damage. A creature that takes cold damage in this way is @UUID[Compendium.pf2e.conditionitems.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round.

action->Aura of Discarded Things.name: Aura of Discarded Things
action->Aura of Discarded Things.description: 30 feet. Items in the emanation can't regain Hit Points unless the effect that attempts to repair them counteracts the aura, which has a counteract rank of 5 and a counteract DC of 30.

consumable->Potion of Flying (Standard).name: Potion of Flying (Standard)
consumable->Potion of Flying (Standard).description:
Upon drinking this effervescent concoction, you gain a fly Speed of 40 feet for 1 minute.

@UUID[Compendium.pf2e.equipment-effects.Item.Mf9EBLhYmZerf0nS]{Effect: Potion of Flying (Standard)}

action->Cold Tolerant.name: Cold Tolerant
action->Cold Tolerant.description: Yana treats environmental cold effects as if they were one step less extreme.

action->Evasion.name: Evasion
action->Evasion.description: When Yana rolls a success on a Reflex save, he gets a critical success instead.
